subject: Re: [junit] black box or white box?
msgSnippet: ... Well, yes. I m assuming that I wrote both the tests and the production code to pass it. This point was merely stating the obvious. ... Redundant is *not*
messageBody:
Quoting Johannes Link <john.link@...>:

> > * Test everything that could possibly break in the current
> implementation
>
> How do you know that an inplementation cannot break? By looking at it
> I
> assume...

Well, yes. I'm assuming that I wrote both the tests and the production code to
pass it. This point was merely stating the obvious.

> > * Are sufficiently implementation-independent to support easier
> refactoring
>
> When your tests only use the public interfaces they usually don't
> break
> during refactoring. They might become redundant, i.e. worthless, when
> you
> test a special case which is no special case in the new refactored
> implementation any more.

Redundant is *not* worthless in this case! If you refactor again, later, the
redundant tests may no longer be redundant. That was the thrust of this second
point: it's not enough to cover the current implementation, one must try to
cover the problem with one's tests. The idea is to have a set of tests that
would indicate whether any reasonable implementation of the feature would work.
I'm not saying that this is easy.

> > * Run quickly, are small, easy to read...
> >
> > I realize that these are competing forces, so the challenge is
> striking
> the
> > right balance. I find my life difficult when my tests get in the way
> of my
> > refactorings... tests that have intimate knowledge of the
> implementation
> tend
> > to be refactoring-resistant. I tend away from them if I can.
>
> That's a very [g]ood heuristic for deciding if it's worth writing a test
> or
> not: asking if the test will probably stay around with the next
> functionality or not. This is my biggest concern I have with doing
> endo-testing using mock objects.
>
> Where do you think our views still differ?

I'm not sure they do, and I wasn't necessarily trying to get into a long
discussion of white box v. black box. JUnit allows both, and anyway, one man's
black box is another man's white box.
